docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Bribes for the Doctors" (editorial, Oct. 15):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:   Re "Bribes for the Doctors" (editorial, Oct. 15):

docs.lead_paragraph: Next fall, just weeks before the 1996 Presidential election, elderly Americans may be deluged with information about private health plans that they can choose as alternatives to the standard Medicare program. If Republicans have their way, people 65 and older would sign up for health maintenance organizations or other types of private health insurance, just as many workers under 65 now choose health plans once a year. The Government would pay most of the cost for Medicare beneficiaries, just as private employers often pay for their employees.

headline.main: Medicare Recipients May Get New Choices

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Bill Bradley announced today that he planned to travel to California next week to listen to people "and try to figure out if some of my ideas about where people are, are correct." When the New Jersey Democrat announced in August that he would not run for a fourth term in the Senate, he said he was considering an independent Presidential candidacy. Asked today if his travels were preliminary to a run for the White House, he said, "This is not about a candidacy -- at this time." He continued, "But it is about trying to reconnect the political process to people's lives."

headline.main: A Noncandidate, Bradley Plans an Issue-Oriented Trip

docs.lead_paragraph: The sweeping cuts in Medicare making their way through Congress would force major teaching and public hospitals around the nation to retrench drastically or face closure, and to slash doctor-training programs that are the backbone of medical care in many poor neighborhoods, according to health care experts. The bitter debates over Medicare have focused on its role as the nation's health care system for the elderly. But the $178 billion program is also the largest subsidizer of medical training in the country, and helps hospitals serving poor and uninsured patients.

headline.main: PUBLIC HOSPITALS FACING DEEP CUTS IN MEDICARE BILL

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Bribes for the Doctors" (editorial, Oct. 15):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:         Re "Bribes for the Doctors" (editorial, Oct. 15):

docs.lead_paragraph: Inmates at county jails and state prisons would have to pay for their own medical care under a bill that was passed by the Senate yesterday and sent to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. The bill would allow counties and the state to be reimbursed for medical costs either from an inmate's personal expense account or from his or her medical insurance. But no inmate would be denied medical care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from remarks today by representatives during the House debate on Medicare legislation, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times: Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem

headline.main: Excerpts From House Debate on G.O.P. Plan to Overhaul Medicare System

docs.snippet: Following are excerpts from remarks today by representatives during the House debate on Medicare legislation, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times:      Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem

docs.lead_paragraph: Beneath the surface, the debate in the House of Representatives today was not so much about the Medicare program itself as it was about partisan politics: about whether the Republican revolution will succeed and about whether Democrats can recapture the glory of the New Deal and the Great Society. The politicians may agree on little else, but they agree on this: Next year's elections and those for years to come could turn on how the public perceives the votes this year on Medicare.

headline.main: Past All the Talk, Some True Goals

docs.snippet: Beneath the surface, the debate in the House of Representatives today was not so much about the Medicare program itself as it was about partisan politics: about whether the Republican revolution will succeed and about whether Democrats can recapture...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Medicare bill passed today by the House of Representatives would propel elderly people into a new world, full of promise and some peril, where competitive forces are buffeting doctors, hospitals and the rest of the health care industry. For better or worse, Medicare is catching up with the private health care market. Even if President Clinton vetoes it, as he has threatened, the bill signals the direction in which health policy and the nation's health care system are already evolving.

headline.main: For Elderly, Bill Promises Entry Into a Market of Shifting Forces

docs.snippet: The Medicare bill passed today by the House of Representatives would propel elderly people into a new world, full of promise and some peril, where competitive forces are buffeting doctors, hospitals and the rest of the health care industry.        ...

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans took a giant step today toward dismantling decades of Democratic social policy, passing legislation to curb Medicare spending and encourage the elderly to turn to private managed-care organizations from the traditional Government plan that has served them since 1965. The vote was 231 to 201, as 4 Democrats joined 227 Republicans in favor of the bill, while 6 Republicans, 194 Democrats and 1 independent voted against it.
